channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Discovery Invests in Digital Textbooks in Hopes of Growth
item.description: Under pressure to expand, media companies are capitalizing on the changes that technology is bringing to classrooms.
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES and AMY CHOZICK
item.media:credit: Chris Keane for The New York Times
item.media:description: Last year, Discovery introduced its line of digital textbooks, called Techbooks. The manuals are used at Mooresville Middle School in North Carolina.

item.title: Merchants and Shoppers Sour on Daily Deal Sites Like Groupon
item.description: After an initial flush of enthusiasm, merchants have grown wary of daily deal Web sites like Groupon and LivingSocial. Now consumers are starting to follow.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Panic Radiates From Indian State of Assam
item.description: What began as a vicious if obscure fight over land and power between Muslims and an indigenous tribe in a remote state has set off panic among northeastern migrants across India.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: People from northeastern India boarded a train bound for Guwahati, in Assam State, at a railway station in Bangalore on Thursday.

item.title: Bits Blog: Apple Becomes Most Valuable Public Company Ever, With an Asterisk
item.description: On Monday Apple became the most highly valued public company ever, but Microsoft still holds the record when its 1999 value is adjusted for inflation.
item.dc:creator: By NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Secrets Learned in Apple-Samsung Trial
item.description: The problem when companies go to trial is that the public gets to hear corporate secrets.
item.dc:creator: By NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Disruptions: Disruptions: The Next Wave for the Wristwatch
item.description: Instead of killing the wristwatch, the smartphone is actually rejuvenating it, and many of the top technology companies have their eyes on your wrist.
item.dc:creator: By NICK BILTON
item.media:description: The Sony Smartwatch allows people to control their phones remotely.

item.title: The iEconomy: New Wave of Deft Robots Is Changing Global Industry
item.description: A new wave of robots is replacing workers in both manufacturing and distribution.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: While the many robots in auto factories typically perform only one function, in the new Tesla factory in Fremont, Calif., a robot might do up to four: welding, riveting, bonding and installing a component.

item.title: You for Sale: Electronic Scores Rank Consumers by Potential Value
item.description: Buying-power scores, compiled from huge amounts of data, measure your potential value as a customer. But you’ll probably never learn your total.
item.dc:creator: By NATASHA SINGER

item.title: Preoccupations: Sharing Too Much Information in the Workplace
item.description: Whether recounting drunken exploits or their searches for new jobs, 20-somethings and others may offer too much information in the workplace.
item.dc:creator: By PEGGY KLAUS

item.title: Assange Accuses U.S. of ‘Witch Hunt’ Against WikiLeaks
item.description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, took to the balcony of Ecuador’s embassy in London to condemn the United States government.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Julian Assange spoke from a balcony at the Ecuadoran embassy in London on Sunday.

item.title: Coming Next: Doctors Prescribing Apps to Patients
item.description: Apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen — and can be reimbursed by insurance — will soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients.
item.dc:creator: By JOSHUA BRUSTEIN
item.media:credit: Steve Ruark for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anand K. Iyer, president of WellDoc, which is marketing the DiabetesManager app.

item.title: Verdict in Apple-Samsung Trial May Echo Through Tech Industry
item.description: If Apple prevails in its legal dogfight with Samsung over patents, experts believe its rivals will have a stronger incentive to distinguish their smartphone and tablet products.
item.dc:creator: By NICK WINGFIELD
item.media:description: Samsung's tablet and Apple's iPad are compared in this evidence image presented during the trial between the two companies over patents.

item.title: App City: Spinlister and Social Bicycles Develop Bike-Sharing Alternatives
item.description: New York’s Citi Bike program has been delayed, but two Web-based start-ups are working on alternatives to Citi Bike.
item.dc:creator: By JOSHUA BRUSTEIN

item.title: Gadgetwise Blog: A New Twist on an Old Phone Swindle
item.description: Swindlers may be making annoying repeat phone calls to entice people to make a return call - resulting in big phone fees.
item.dc:creator: By ROY FURCHGOTT

item.title: Victor Poor, Intel Computer Chip Innovator, Dies at 79
item.description: Mr. Poor, a computer engineer and amateur radio enthusiast, collaborated on development of microprocessors that propelled Intel to dominance in the computer chip industry.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARKOFF

item.title: Gadgetwise Blog: Tip of the Week: Customizing iOS Notifications
item.description: In Apple's iOS software, you can choose which apps you want to see in your Notification Center and the style of the alert messages themselves.
item.dc:creator: By J.D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Bits Blog: Square Offers Flat-Rate Plan for Small Businesses
item.description: Square will drop the processing fees for small businesses using its service, offering a flat-rate plan in an effort to entice more of them to sign up.
item.dc:creator: By JENNA WORTHAM

item.title: Bits Blog: Judge Raises New Questions About Facebook Advertising Tactic
item.description: At a time when Facebook needs to increase its revenue, a federal judge in California rejected the proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit targeting the company's most lucrative advertising tool.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Big City: The Watchmen’s Misdirected Gaze
item.description: Surveillance cameras are omnipresent in the post 9/11 world, but they have been focused least on where they are needed most: high-crime areas.
item.dc:creator: By GINIA BELLAFANTE
item.media:description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg introduced a citywide security system earlier this month.

item.title: Julian Assange Under Watch at Ecuadorean Embassy
item.description: Officers in London who have been ordered to prevent Julian Assange, the fugitive WikiLeaks founder, from leaving the country have had him under constant surveillance.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: To prevent Julian Assange from fleeing, police officers kept watch outside the Ecuadorean Embassy in London on Friday.

item.title: Fundamentally: Dividend-Paying Stocks, Found in Unusual Places
item.description: Utility and telecommunications stocks are the traditional dividend payers, but investors now have other places to turn for income, including technology stocks.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL J. LIM

item.title: The Haggler: Samsung and a Reader’s Printer Problem — the Haggler
item.description: A reader seeks the Haggler’s aid in solving a problem with a Samsung printer. But the Haggler then finds his own problem in trying to deal with an “anonymous spokesperson” for the company.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Poetic Connections | Facebook: Missed Connections Poetry on Craigslist
item.description: When future scholars data-mine the Internet for a digital literature of romance, they are sure to find all of its aspects on Facebook.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN FEUER

item.title: Bits Blog: Twitter Changes Lead to Online Protests
item.description: After Twitter imposed stricter rules for third-party apps on Thursday, engineers and developers picked up their pitchforks and took to Twitter and blogs to decry what some likened to a "bait and switch."
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH and NICK BILTON

item.title: National Briefing | West: Ipad Stolen From Home of Steve Jobs Is Found in Clown’s Hands
item.description: A professional clown who played music on an iPad as he made balloon animals said on Friday that he had no idea his friend had snatched the tablet from the home of Steve Jobs.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
